number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												After being an avid fan of the entire Civilization series, especially III and IV, since I was old enough to understand the strategy of them when they were released, I remember becoming rather psyched up when I heard of the impending release of this game. It was an interesting start to a lovely relationship.Any Civ fan from before Civ V will remember the interesting and controversial spoilers: No religion? Shame. No unit stacking? Brave. Hexagonal tiles? Scandal!For those who had not been indoctrinated with the traditions of previous Civ games, I'll admit, the forums all looked a bit silly. Eventually, a demo was released, and I installed it and played it, all 100 turns of it, and I wasn't impressed. It was all a bit boring. And that was the end of that. I wasn't going to spend a wad of my hard-earned dole money on a game that wasn't amazing. I would just play Civ IV instead.Then, one late Spring day almost four years later, a Steam sale tugged at the heartstrings of my throat, and beckoned me and my wallet to join it in virtual matrimony, and, in a whim of impetuous and spontaneous peer pressure, I bought it, and the complete edition with all of its DLC at that. It's the best whim I've ever had on a late Spring day almost four years after Civ V was released.It is a pretty game. It is easy to learn to play. You don't have to micromanage, although if, like me, you want to, then it is quite possible to manage most microscopically. Religions were introduced in the expansion packs, and they work very well. Hexagons are a lovely shape, and I find them even more accomodating than those old squares (Just ask the Settlers). The music is fabulous, unless you play as an African or Middle-Eastern nation, in which case you mostly get wind instruments that sound like dying animals, but other than that, the music is fabulous. The lack of animations for wonders and victories was slightly disappointing, but the artwork that takes its place is marvelous. A nice man narrates the technologies rather nicely, although everyone prefers Leonard Nimoy from Civ IV. The gameplay, although a broad topic, can suitably be described as good. As might be expected, it is difficult to try to lose on the easiest difficulties, and impossibly hard on the hardest. The leaders and nations available are colourful and exciting, and we can still become best friends with Catherine the Great. The civilopedia entries are very useful for the game, of course, but also contain real history and information which is well-written, and which I have personally spent hours reading in the middle of a game. The Steam achievements connected with the game are hilarious, and when you read them, make you want to cross your arms and say to yourself: "challenge accepted."I could go on, but I realise that, in summary, it may be best to conclude by preparing any potential player to adopt the correct mental attitude. This is not an expansion pack to Civ IV, obviously, so don't treat it like one. It is more like a younger brother to it than a son. It's different, and there may be parts of it you don't like, such as hexagons or city-capture or the way he smacks his mouth when he eats his breakfast. But I don't see any reason why, even if you have a preference, you can't be friends with both.Please enjoy this game very much, and be careful with that Attila fellow. He can't be trusted.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2012
												Civilization V is as much a lateral step away from the complicated nature of Civ IV as it is a step forward in the franchise's vaunted history. Most importantly, after 18 months, Civ 5 has improved dramatically from the game it was upon release. The AI is improved, key game concepts have been buffed and nerfed, as needed. And there is welcome, but not critical, DLC.What I love about this version: hex-based game board for more natural movement. No more stacks of doom. Global happiness. No tech trading. Drastically improved AI relations. Improved event notification system means you never miss a beat.What I dislike: The tech tree has been significantly flattened from Civ 4. Tech and Culture victories are terribly boring to achieve: hunker down, press "next turn", repeat 200 times. Overreliance on gold farming to buy off all problems.Overall - a successful attempt to streamline gameplay without removing core elements. Civ 5 is a success, and I welcome the coming expansion(s).

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I've been saying to myself "this is the last turn i swear", but i'm just not able to quit. These are the problems that show up as soon as you begin understanding the fundementals of this game.Sid Meier's Civlization V is a turn-based 4x game, where you manage you cities and make sure your people are well fed and happy. The goal in this game is to be the most progressive population on the planet. You start out with a city that fits the population you've chosen. From here on out you start exploring and building things. With the first unit, you will find things like ruins and barbarian camps. The barbarians are your first real enemy, you will have to try to fight them off while progressing your first city. When you start expanding alot you find out that the barbarians are not a real threat anymore. In fact you will be alot more busy with the other populations on the map. The other populations can be friendly but also an enemy. This is where diplomacy comes in, some leaders of the populations may trick you and create traps to backstab you after a while, so you have to be carefull on what you decide what's best. You also get to trade and discuss with these leaders, for instance, you could trade a luxury that your population wishes for.After a couple of hundered turns you'll get the hang of it and start liking the game alot, for me it's the progressing that makes me hooked to this game. it's the mentality of "just finishing this one thing" that makes it soo addicting to me.I find it to be one of the best games i have every played. This is the first civilization game i ever played, but now i regret that i never played the previous parts of this series. All in all a great game! I highly recommend it!

												I would definitely have to say that I thoroughly enjoy Civilization V. Civ 5 is up in my top ranked games, and many reasons got it there. One would be the fact that you can see your own civilization progress through the ages, which I find to be a very interesting concept. Should I list all of the reasons in this review, it would be a good 5 pages long, so instead, I'm just going to say that I highly recommend this game, just make sure that you have the patience for it. Finally, as I'm sure has been said in most reviews, I would say that although this game is great, like an actual empire, it takes the collaboration of all of the components to work swimmingly, that being said in simpler terms, this game is only worth it with all of the DLC that is available for purchase. It may be a sum of extra money for some, but it will be worth it in the end. If you are a bargain hunter though, then wait until a huge sale, such as the summer or winter sale, and get the game with all of the DLC for less than the price of the game alone when it's not on sale. That's all from me, so happy gaming!

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												I'm not huge on 4x games, but my recent time playing one in particular (Thea: The Awakening) reminded me of how fun they can be. I had this just sitting in my library, and it hooked me quick. It can be pretty slow paced, that's for sure, but that's the nature of this type of game; I recommend it if you have any bit of patience, or are a fan of board games with lots of intricacies to learn. Otherwise, this is not likely for you.Civilization, along with pretty much other strategy game, is for the thinking man, always looking at the long-run benefits. Civ in particular, though, has always had several options for you to go about achieving your victory, most of them relatively peaceful. It's not hard to see why they pump out sequels.PROS:* Models and textures are surprisingly high quality, both on and off the board.* Soundtrack is varied, pleasant, and changes seamlessly to fit what's happening. Could range from anything to a wartime theme complete with trumpets and drums, to something you'd hear at a classical ball.* As always, the narration and voice work in general is on point.* Customizable to the extreme in almost every aspect--gameplay, UI, tutorial hints, graphics, sound--if you can think it, this game can do it. As advertised, it seems to be capable of running on any rig with no trouble.* Bonus points for upgrading from square tiles to a hex grid.I struggle to think of any cons for this one. The whole game's mechanically sound, it's tuneable, everything is as-advertised, and it's got polish (pun intended). If you're looking forward to Civ VI and haven't already done so, snag this one, at least when it goes on sale, it's the best game of the series by a long-shot.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												After being an avid fan of the entire Civilization series, especially III and IV, since I was old enough to understand the strategy of them when they were released, I remember becoming rather psyched up when I heard of the impending release of this game. It was an interesting start to a lovely relationship.Any Civ fan from before Civ V will remember the interesting and controversial spoilers: No religion? Shame. No unit stacking? Brave. Hexagonal tiles? Scandal!For those who had not been indoctrinated with the traditions of previous Civ games, I'll admit, the forums all looked a bit silly. Eventually, a demo was released, and I installed it and played it, all 100 turns of it, and I wasn't impressed. It was all a bit boring. And that was the end of that. I wasn't going to spend a wad of my hard-earned dole money on a game that wasn't amazing. I would just play Civ IV instead.Then, one late Spring day almost four years later, a Steam sale tugged at the heartstrings of my throat, and beckoned me and my wallet to join it in virtual matrimony, and, in a whim of impetuous and spontaneous peer pressure, I bought it, and the complete edition with all of its DLC at that. It's the best whim I've ever had on a late Spring day almost four years after Civ V was released.It is a pretty game. It is easy to learn to play. You don't have to micromanage, although if, like me, you want to, then it is quite possible to manage most microscopically. Religions were introduced in the expansion packs, and they work very well. Hexagons are a lovely shape, and I find them even more accomodating than those old squares (Just ask the Settlers). The music is fabulous, unless you play as an African or Middle-Eastern nation, in which case you mostly get wind instruments that sound like dying animals, but other than that, the music is fabulous. The lack of animations for wonders and victories was slightly disappointing, but the artwork that takes its place is marvelous. A nice man narrates the technologies rather nicely, although everyone prefers Leonard Nimoy from Civ IV. The gameplay, although a broad topic, can suitably be described as good. As might be expected, it is difficult to try to lose on the easiest difficulties, and impossibly hard on the hardest. The leaders and nations available are colourful and exciting, and we can still become best friends with Catherine the Great. The civilopedia entries are very useful for the game, of course, but also contain real history and information which is well-written, and which I have personally spent hours reading in the middle of a game. The Steam achievements connected with the game are hilarious, and when you read them, make you want to cross your arms and say to yourself: "challenge accepted."I could go on, but I realise that, in summary, it may be best to conclude by preparing any potential player to adopt the correct mental attitude. This is not an expansion pack to Civ IV, obviously, so don't treat it like one. It is more like a younger brother to it than a son. It's different, and there may be parts of it you don't like, such as hexagons or city-capture or the way he smacks his mouth when he eats his breakfast. But I don't see any reason why, even if you have a preference, you can't be friends with both.Please enjoy this game very much, and be careful with that Attila fellow. He can't be trusted.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												What more can be send about argumentatively the most addictive game series ever? Coining the phrase 'just one more turn', the Civilization series has a track record of stealing precious hours from its enthralled fans. I started out with Civ 2 and was instantly hooked, helpless to its alluring and seductive gameplay.  I resisted buying Civ 5 for so long. I loved Civ 4, and played it so much that I decided to give the series a break for a while. That turned out to be years, with the occasional game here and there. I could no longer resist when I saw the Civ 5: complete bundle on sale for $12 earlier this year. In terms of value of content, it doesn't get much better than this!I'm sure many of you reading this are familiar with the game mechanics. Civ 5 has simplified aspects of the game from Civ 4, which actually has made the game better in many ways. For example, I used to get frustrated with the number of units a player could stack up on a single tile. I found it to be deceptive, as only one unit type would show up on the tile. Thankfully, Civ 5 only allows one unit to occupy a tile. Thank you, Sid! There are other changes, but for the purpose of this review I will stop myself.Although the game is already 6 years old, the graphics are still great! The soundtrack is also at a very high standard; I would be happy to listen to the opening music for hours. The music in the game is equally as good, giving the player always something nice to listen to. If you are a Civ fan and haven't bought this yet, do! If you are new to the series and unsure, I suggest buying the Civ 5: Complete bundle when on sale. The expansion packs and dlc adds even more gameplay elements, scenarios, and maps (to an already huge offering!). The only thing that should be a decisive factor is whether you have the time to play it. If you enjoy brilliant turn-based strategy games, once you start a game you won't have much time for much else!Buy it at your own peril! I'll give Civ 6 another few years...

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												Warning - I'm a fan of Civilization games from the beginning; consider this review may have some positive bias.  ;-) And, this review assumes you can read the basic description of the game in the Store; not going to repeat that.Likes:Social Policy System --   A better way to achieve a Cultural victory while helping with other victory conditions.  A needed replacement for the "Civics" feature of the prior Civ game.  The new system offers a great variety of paths to get to Cultural victory.  And, it can be integral in developing strategic advantages and it directly supports other victory conditions.Tactical Game Play -- Hex tiles; what a concept.  Finally!  Partial damage to units is also an improvement, although a 100% healthy unit can be destroyed if up against a much stronger unit.  Lack of stacking combat units may bother some, but in context of the changes in tactical play, it works very well.  The aspect of tactical game play has improved.City Defense -- Cities can now defend themselves without a garrison, which improves upon the siege concept.  With a garrison, some strength is added to the city.  Requiring a garrison didn't add much to the game; other than the concern for a stupid, instant death by having no garrison.City-States -- A useful addition to the game.  As an Ally, you may get two or three types of benefits: food, strategic resources, luxuries, culture, and military units.  Their allegiance can be bought for much gold, but it is best when they offer opportunities to win their favor.  After getting their favor, you get some influence so moving to Ally with money is cheaper.  As an Ally, they will go to war with you, automatically.  Although, they are not very effective except possibly as a distraction to your enemy.Dislikes:A bug or two or three --  1. I prefer multiplayer, either competitive or coop.  Unfortunately, when resuming a saved game with AI, the AI gets an extra turn.  We have tried using the Auto-Save versions or the directly saved versions, but it seems to always happen to us.  I try not to save when we are at war; that can be really bad giving the AI a free turn.  2. Workers sometimes stop what they are working on.  This is with no enemy action nearby, (not at war).  It is necessary to click on them and re-order the action.  This applies to building single-tile improvements, or directing a range of action like laying a railroad upon an existing road.Some things I'm glad are gone from some prior versions, but that's just me:Religion -- In Vanilla there is no religion aspect.  I actually liked it in some prior versions, but I see now with it gone, it really doesn't matter to me.  It would be more managing and strategizing, but I'm happy with all that I must do in this current version.Corporations -- Same as with Religion.  It was nice, but I can easily live without it.Stacking combat units -- Stacking was nice in that you could use combined arms effects by putting a defensive unit stacked with an offensive unit.  I liked the flexibility that gave the player.  Civ 5 doesn't have stacking, but it has made other changes to the tactical game that are an improvement.  Also, I like now that a front line is generally bigger in hex coverage.  That makes for a better feel of a real battle.  Stacking units was, in the end, rather boring.Conclusion:The game of Civilization has gone through many changes for a game.  The trend was adding more and more characteristics of the real world.  It was becoming more and more involved and complex.  Although, as with every Civ I've played, it's not strictly necessary to play in a very complex style to achieve victory.  Indeed, some versions took that to a fault resulting in easy quick kills to win the game.By reducing some of the complexity, (adding Social Policy and City-States some would say they haven't), they have come up with an extremely playable version of Civilization.  And for those that want back some of the removed complexity, the Expansion Packs will fill that need.  In Civ 5, they have not sacrificed any of the key strategic concepts and they have improved upon some.  And, they have most definately improved upon the tactical level.  I will be playing this game for a long time.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												I would definitely recommend this game to people like these sorts of a games and strategy games in general.I'm not gonna make a long review, but I'm gonna list a few pros, cons and at the end an overview/conclusion. PROS:  Huge replayability, every 'playthrough' is different There is a playstyle for nearly everyone (if you have the Brave New World DLC; we'll get back to that later) The multiplayer is very fun, especially when you go after the domination victory. The workshop is filled with mods, that add civs, mechanics, scenarios, which all add to the replayability of this game. CONS:  I have never played without the DLCs (except in multiplayer) but from what I've heard and seen, without the DLC, Civilization V is not as enjoyable, so I could only recommend it with the DLCs.Without the DLCs there are also about 20 less civilizations to play, so a lot of playstyles (strategies) can't really be played without them. The AI can be pretty moronic (surprisingly so in Multiplayer [e.g. I'll give you Sugar for all your Resources]) and do pretty dumb things, like declare war on civilisations halfway across the world. CONCLUSION: All in all, I could only recommend buying this game (with all addons), especially if it's on sale and you can get all the DLCs with the game for only 11 Euros or so (like me).It's one of my favourite games and I'm definitely going to be playing a lot more.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												Warning - I'm a fan of Civilization games from the beginning; consider this review may have some positive bias.  ;-) And, this review assumes you can read the basic description of the game in the Store; not going to repeat that.Likes:Social Policy System --   A better way to achieve a Cultural victory while helping with other victory conditions.  A needed replacement for the "Civics" feature of the prior Civ game.  The new system offers a great variety of paths to get to Cultural victory.  And, it can be integral in developing strategic advantages and it directly supports other victory conditions.Tactical Game Play -- Hex tiles; what a concept.  Finally!  Partial damage to units is also an improvement, although a 100% healthy unit can be destroyed if up against a much stronger unit.  Lack of stacking combat units may bother some, but in context of the changes in tactical play, it works very well.  The aspect of tactical game play has improved.City Defense -- Cities can now defend themselves without a garrison, which improves upon the siege concept.  With a garrison, some strength is added to the city.  Requiring a garrison didn't add much to the game; other than the concern for a stupid, instant death by having no garrison.City-States -- A useful addition to the game.  As an Ally, you may get two or three types of benefits: food, strategic resources, luxuries, culture, and military units.  Their allegiance can be bought for much gold, but it is best when they offer opportunities to win their favor.  After getting their favor, you get some influence so moving to Ally with money is cheaper.  As an Ally, they will go to war with you, automatically.  Although, they are not very effective except possibly as a distraction to your enemy.Dislikes:A bug or two or three --  1. I prefer multiplayer, either competitive or coop.  Unfortunately, when resuming a saved game with AI, the AI gets an extra turn.  We have tried using the Auto-Save versions or the directly saved versions, but it seems to always happen to us.  I try not to save when we are at war; that can be really bad giving the AI a free turn.  2. Workers sometimes stop what they are working on.  This is with no enemy action nearby, (not at war).  It is necessary to click on them and re-order the action.  This applies to building single-tile improvements, or directing a range of action like laying a railroad upon an existing road.Some things I'm glad are gone from some prior versions, but that's just me:Religion -- In Vanilla there is no religion aspect.  I actually liked it in some prior versions, but I see now with it gone, it really doesn't matter to me.  It would be more managing and strategizing, but I'm happy with all that I must do in this current version.Corporations -- Same as with Religion.  It was nice, but I can easily live without it.Stacking combat units -- Stacking was nice in that you could use combined arms effects by putting a defensive unit stacked with an offensive unit.  I liked the flexibility that gave the player.  Civ 5 doesn't have stacking, but it has made other changes to the tactical game that are an improvement.  Also, I like now that a front line is generally bigger in hex coverage.  That makes for a better feel of a real battle.  Stacking units was, in the end, rather boring.Conclusion:The game of Civilization has gone through many changes for a game.  The trend was adding more and more characteristics of the real world.  It was becoming more and more involved and complex.  Although, as with every Civ I've played, it's not strictly necessary to play in a very complex style to achieve victory.  Indeed, some versions took that to a fault resulting in easy quick kills to win the game.By reducing some of the complexity, (adding Social Policy and City-States some would say they haven't), they have come up with an extremely playable version of Civilization.  And for those that want back some of the removed complexity, the Expansion Packs will fill that need.  In Civ 5, they have not sacrificed any of the key strategic concepts and they have improved upon some.  And, they have most definately improved upon the tactical level.  I will be playing this game for a long time.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												I would definitely recommend this game to people like these sorts of a games and strategy games in general.I'm not gonna make a long review, but I'm gonna list a few pros, cons and at the end an overview/conclusion. PROS:  Huge replayability, every 'playthrough' is different There is a playstyle for nearly everyone (if you have the Brave New World DLC; we'll get back to that later) The multiplayer is very fun, especially when you go after the domination victory. The workshop is filled with mods, that add civs, mechanics, scenarios, which all add to the replayability of this game. CONS:  I have never played without the DLCs (except in multiplayer) but from what I've heard and seen, without the DLC, Civilization V is not as enjoyable, so I could only recommend it with the DLCs.Without the DLCs there are also about 20 less civilizations to play, so a lot of playstyles (strategies) can't really be played without them. The AI can be pretty moronic (surprisingly so in Multiplayer [e.g. I'll give you Sugar for all your Resources]) and do pretty dumb things, like declare war on civilisations halfway across the world. CONCLUSION: All in all, I could only recommend buying this game (with all addons), especially if it's on sale and you can get all the DLCs with the game for only 11 Euros or so (like me).It's one of my favourite games and I'm definitely going to be playing a lot more.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												What more can be send about argumentatively the most addictive game series ever? Coining the phrase 'just one more turn', the Civilization series has a track record of stealing precious hours from its enthralled fans. I started out with Civ 2 and was instantly hooked, helpless to its alluring and seductive gameplay.  I resisted buying Civ 5 for so long. I loved Civ 4, and played it so much that I decided to give the series a break for a while. That turned out to be years, with the occasional game here and there. I could no longer resist when I saw the Civ 5: complete bundle on sale for $12 earlier this year. In terms of value of content, it doesn't get much better than this!I'm sure many of you reading this are familiar with the game mechanics. Civ 5 has simplified aspects of the game from Civ 4, which actually has made the game better in many ways. For example, I used to get frustrated with the number of units a player could stack up on a single tile. I found it to be deceptive, as only one unit type would show up on the tile. Thankfully, Civ 5 only allows one unit to occupy a tile. Thank you, Sid! There are other changes, but for the purpose of this review I will stop myself.Although the game is already 6 years old, the graphics are still great! The soundtrack is also at a very high standard; I would be happy to listen to the opening music for hours. The music in the game is equally as good, giving the player always something nice to listen to. If you are a Civ fan and haven't bought this yet, do! If you are new to the series and unsure, I suggest buying the Civ 5: Complete bundle when on sale. The expansion packs and dlc adds even more gameplay elements, scenarios, and maps (to an already huge offering!). The only thing that should be a decisive factor is whether you have the time to play it. If you enjoy brilliant turn-based strategy games, once you start a game you won't have much time for much else!Buy it at your own peril! I'll give Civ 6 another few years...

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												One of the best turn based 4x strategy games out there. Civilization V is vastly improved by the expansions Gods & Kings and Brave New World so I would reccommend picking those up if you are considering Civilization V. This game is great at allowing you to expand your civilizations through any way possible whether it be by war, diplomacy, or your economy. The game doesn't stale as you head into the late game because of the World Congress and Idealogies you are able to pick up once you get closer to the Atomic Era. Idealogies does a great job of creating rivals and allies as you align with the people you share Idealogies with.This game is relatively easy to run and can be accessible to most poeple. The multiplayer is fun if you can find friends to play with as it is more interesting playing with people you known. There are some faults with multiplayer as the game will often reload itself for no apparent reason.Overall great game and is a must own for anyone that enjoes 4x strategy games.

												Arguably one of the, if not the best series of geo-political history strategy games to ever exist. Its creator Sid Meier has renowned this game to fulfill most aspects to create a realistic strategy game that could be tackled in endless ways and mediums.Succeeding a disappointing Civilization IV, Civilization 5 has introduced a hexa-grid game style giving the game a new graphical and strategic taste. In addition the ongoing integrating community has produced great mods which have even made the game more realistic than ever along its HD graphics such as the EARTH 2014 MOD where one could tackle the political obstacles as a modern political leader in the real world. da3ouk

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I've been saying to myself "this is the last turn i swear", but i'm just not able to quit. These are the problems that show up as soon as you begin understanding the fundementals of this game.Sid Meier's Civlization V is a turn-based 4x game, where you manage you cities and make sure your people are well fed and happy. The goal in this game is to be the most progressive population on the planet. You start out with a city that fits the population you've chosen. From here on out you start exploring and building things. With the first unit, you will find things like ruins and barbarian camps. The barbarians are your first real enemy, you will have to try to fight them off while progressing your first city. When you start expanding alot you find out that the barbarians are not a real threat anymore. In fact you will be alot more busy with the other populations on the map. The other populations can be friendly but also an enemy. This is where diplomacy comes in, some leaders of the populations may trick you and create traps to backstab you after a while, so you have to be carefull on what you decide what's best. You also get to trade and discuss with these leaders, for instance, you could trade a luxury that your population wishes for.After a couple of hundered turns you'll get the hang of it and start liking the game alot, for me it's the progressing that makes me hooked to this game. it's the mentality of "just finishing this one thing" that makes it soo addicting to me.I find it to be one of the best games i have every played. This is the first civilization game i ever played, but now i regret that i never played the previous parts of this series. All in all a great game! I highly recommend it!

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												Warning - I'm a fan of Civilization games from the beginning; consider this review may have some positive bias.  ;-) And, this review assumes you can read the basic description of the game in the Store; not going to repeat that.Likes:Social Policy System --   A better way to achieve a Cultural victory while helping with other victory conditions.  A needed replacement for the "Civics" feature of the prior Civ game.  The new system offers a great variety of paths to get to Cultural victory.  And, it can be integral in developing strategic advantages and it directly supports other victory conditions.Tactical Game Play -- Hex tiles; what a concept.  Finally!  Partial damage to units is also an improvement, although a 100% healthy unit can be destroyed if up against a much stronger unit.  Lack of stacking combat units may bother some, but in context of the changes in tactical play, it works very well.  The aspect of tactical game play has improved.City Defense -- Cities can now defend themselves without a garrison, which improves upon the siege concept.  With a garrison, some strength is added to the city.  Requiring a garrison didn't add much to the game; other than the concern for a stupid, instant death by having no garrison.City-States -- A useful addition to the game.  As an Ally, you may get two or three types of benefits: food, strategic resources, luxuries, culture, and military units.  Their allegiance can be bought for much gold, but it is best when they offer opportunities to win their favor.  After getting their favor, you get some influence so moving to Ally with money is cheaper.  As an Ally, they will go to war with you, automatically.  Although, they are not very effective except possibly as a distraction to your enemy.Dislikes:A bug or two or three --  1. I prefer multiplayer, either competitive or coop.  Unfortunately, when resuming a saved game with AI, the AI gets an extra turn.  We have tried using the Auto-Save versions or the directly saved versions, but it seems to always happen to us.  I try not to save when we are at war; that can be really bad giving the AI a free turn.  2. Workers sometimes stop what they are working on.  This is with no enemy action nearby, (not at war).  It is necessary to click on them and re-order the action.  This applies to building single-tile improvements, or directing a range of action like laying a railroad upon an existing road.Some things I'm glad are gone from some prior versions, but that's just me:Religion -- In Vanilla there is no religion aspect.  I actually liked it in some prior versions, but I see now with it gone, it really doesn't matter to me.  It would be more managing and strategizing, but I'm happy with all that I must do in this current version.Corporations -- Same as with Religion.  It was nice, but I can easily live without it.Stacking combat units -- Stacking was nice in that you could use combined arms effects by putting a defensive unit stacked with an offensive unit.  I liked the flexibility that gave the player.  Civ 5 doesn't have stacking, but it has made other changes to the tactical game that are an improvement.  Also, I like now that a front line is generally bigger in hex coverage.  That makes for a better feel of a real battle.  Stacking units was, in the end, rather boring.Conclusion:The game of Civilization has gone through many changes for a game.  The trend was adding more and more characteristics of the real world.  It was becoming more and more involved and complex.  Although, as with every Civ I've played, it's not strictly necessary to play in a very complex style to achieve victory.  Indeed, some versions took that to a fault resulting in easy quick kills to win the game.By reducing some of the complexity, (adding Social Policy and City-States some would say they haven't), they have come up with an extremely playable version of Civilization.  And for those that want back some of the removed complexity, the Expansion Packs will fill that need.  In Civ 5, they have not sacrificed any of the key strategic concepts and they have improved upon some.  And, they have most definately improved upon the tactical level.  I will be playing this game for a long time.

I think that game HAVE balance. All nations have own bonuses. Choice what u like and beat your opponents.8. For newbies — easy to learn.Omg... It's just Civilization, what i can say more?!And... Only one bad sign i can say about Civ V — cropped release version... Because, if you want religion — you will need to buy DLC Gods & Kings... Nobody like that marketing politic.Cheers, Mazy.

												With or without the DLCs this is an amazing game however if you have the choice BUY THE DLCs. To be honest playing with friends is well, kind of annoying, if you have friends like I do (ones that get bored after playing for an hour), so I can't comment much on the multiplayer other than the small games I've played with friends.  When playing single player you can just relax and watch the fallout of your nukes burn your enemies as well as take your time, in multiplayer you'll have your friend constantly telling you to 'END YOUR TURN' which causes a little trickle of salt to flow in. Lets be honest, sooner or later this is going to get a bit boring so why not try mods which are no hassle what so ever when you've got the Steam Workshop there full of great mods. If you're anything like me then you'll love the feeling of having a hyper massive map with one giant nation of the other side of it with so many nukes they could blow up the moon. So yeah, great game. I've spent many hours telling my friend I'll be done soon as they wait impatiently for me to 'finish nuking that c*** Egypt'. Funny story, when I said France had attacked Russia with a nuclear missile my friend thought I was talking about real life before running off and telling everyone about it.He felt pretty stupid once I told him that he was tricked by my intense CIV dialog.  So all in all, yeah. Good game.P.S. Its really easy to learn how to play, like, really easy.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
Note: This review is about Civilization V: Complete Edition. I will not describe the gameplay very deeply. I believe it was described many times in other reviews here on Steam and on many game sites.This game brings back the atmosphere that was in the good old RTS like Rise of Nations or Empire Earth. Choose the civilization you wanto to play as, then guide it from the ancient history to the near future.You can win by conquer every capital city on the map. If you are going to do that, you probably will have to kill everything that stands in your way and conquer all the cities on the way as well. However, there are more victory conditions than just conquer and kill everything. There are more peaceful ways to achieve victory. You can spread your culture to other civilizations. You can become a world leader. Or build a spacecraft and send it to Aplha Centauri. Thanks to this, the game is not only for bloodthirsty warmongers, but also for players who like to play as a peaceful lord. It's also more replayable.Another good point of Civ V is the opportunity of taking history in your hands and change it. What if Zulu was the first nation who sent their spacecraft to Alpha Centauri? Does it hear ridiculous to you? Or what if Napoleon didn't declared himself as the Emperor of France, but was elected as Leader of the World instead? Do you say that it's impossible? Not in this game. This is what I miss in newer games.The game is turn based, so you don't have to hurry. This makes the game relaxing. What makes it even more relaxing is the soundtrack, especially when you play as one of the Middle East civilizations.Another thing that I like about games like this is the fact that you can learn something by just playing them.  Civilopedia, the in-game manual, contains informations not only useful for the gameplay, but also some historical facts.The other way to learn something is to create The Great Works of Arts. They can be produces by Great Writers, Musicians and Artists that are born in your empire. They are named by real persons and the works they create really existed. You can read excerpts from the books, hear parts from the songs and look at the paintings.Sure, you won't gain enough knowledge to teach at Oxford University, but it can raise an interest in you about these things. Well, at least it did in me. There weren't many games with such an impact on me, only Age of Empires II and Rome: Total War, as far as I can remember.I was able to lost myself while playing this game. Many times I told myself "Ok, I will play this for a few minutes". Then I looked at the clock and thought "Well, it's pretty late". I can fully recommend this game for anybody who likes to play strategies."Sir, what will be it today?""We are going for the space victory, James"."What civilization will you send to space, my lord?""We will play as Morocco."After few days..."How is it going, sir?""We are nearly done, my dear James. We have the most delegates in the world congress. The other nations are waging wars against eachother.""What ideology have you chosen, if I may ask you?""We are following the Autocracy ideology.""Pardon my, my lord, but I am not sure if Autocracy is suitable for space victory.""Maybe it isn't, James. But we'll get an achievement for it if we win.""Oh, I understand. How much did you progress in your goal to win the science victory, sir?""Just a few turns and our spacecraft will be ready. Then we will send it to space and we will be the winners.Just a few turns..."

content:
Posted: January 31
												Still one of the very best strategy games around these days. Civ 5 offers a huge diversity of nations, maps and difficulties that makes it easy to spends hundreds to thousands of hours into the game. As a round based game, where you can play solo with AI or together with real players you will face challenging rounds of strategic building, researching and fighting. Diverse troop types, lots of different tiles, many ways to win the match and an overall freedom of choice on how to play make this an all-time fun game. The only downside one can think of is simply the insane amount of time it can take to play - and actually finish - a multiplayer match. Tip: Buying the gold edition surely brings in a lot more bang for you buck. The DLC's available and the DLC's you might actually need differ a lot. Nations and Maps are a nice bonus, but should only be bought in a discounted state.Overall: Totally recommended if you enjoy long sessions of round based strategy with freedom of choice regarding your gameplay.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												I played Civ 2: Test of Time back in the day. It was fun to explore, the city building was interesting, trying out new units was always enjoable, and then of course, marching an army to an opponent was a blast. Fast forward 10 years to Civ 5. Exploration is always fun. Seeking ruins, meeting city states, fending off barbarians and eventually finding your opponents is great. The reasearch tree in this game makes it incredibly difficult to choose: Do I build up my military tech, increase my gold income, push for some good culture wonders, increase my science, grow my city... etc. and every play can be done differently. I have a favourite tech path due to familiarity, but if needed, I will take any road. The variety in strategy for early game exploration, mid game conquests and late game domination is incredibe. I bought this game on the suggestion of a friend and it was the best money I have spent on a game. Do I recommend Civ 5? YES! GET THE GAME! PLAY WITH YOUR FRIENDS!Once you get past the initial learning curve, you will find that the exploration, development, strategy, and eventual victory will be incredibly satisfying and very addictive. I cannot wait for Civilization: Beyond Earth

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Comparing Civilization V to contemporary strategy games is entirely pointless. Imagine if Modern Warfare had come out alongside Quake II. There is simply nothing comparable out there, not least because the strategy genre has become the province of indie developers and niche publishers. Civ V is a towering, AAA release with millions of dollars worth of polish in an era where questionably localized Russian titles are all that strategy gamers have to tide them over for months at a time. It's also a delightfully fresh take on a formula that has been slowly iterated on for more than two decades.The heart of the Civilization fantasy is unchanged. You still manage cities, developing them from rude collections of mud huts into gleaming modern metropolises. Vast armies and armadas are again at your command, waging global war for conquest, defense, or resources with everything from spears to nukes. The land must still be worked, the primordial wilderness tamed through your people’s sweat and blood. Your ultimate goal is yours to choose: Diplomatically unite the people of the world under your benign leadership, launch a viable colony ship into outer space, conquer the globe through force of arms, or create a glorious utopia through enlightened civility.Civ V's genius lies in the way that Firaxis has aggressively chopped the number of decisions that a player has to make during the course of a game while taking away almost none of the meaningful ones. As a hardcore Civ player, I appreciate some of these ancillary aspects of the design, but the removal of all the fat is unquestionably Civ V's greatest accomplishment.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Well then, the time has finally come to review what has occupied my life for the past months. Oh Civ 5, how I underestimated you this past summmer when I saw your GOTY edition on steam. How I was hesitant to buy you and thought your gameplay was boring. If only I knew...I bought this game out of pure review score, which of course -being a 90- I assumed was something special. As many of the steam games that are bought during sales do, it sat on my library quite some time while I was busy murdering Teemos on the Fields of Justice. When I finally got tired of that, I decided to check this game out, so I double clicked on the icon, and went into the game with little to no prior knowledge of what lay in store ahead. I booted up the tutorial, grabbed my water and said, "Well Civ 5, do your worst."I was greeted by a Morgan Freeman like voice, telling me about America and its past, along with some facts about George Washington. This narrator got me so pumped up; the combination of music, the epic dialouge, the VOICE, mother of god THE VOICE, I had so many goosebumps running over my body that I could hardly contain myself! And then I did it, I pressed Begin Your Journey, little did I know this would take me above and beyond what I believed was a true gaming experience. It started out simple, a settler and a warrior unit, and some lady telling me to found a city. I plop it down and start producing a monument, moving my warrior around and reasearching pottery. I found my neighbor soon after, the Incas, and I was greeted by a stunning display screen with a great voice actor and interface. Soon enough I had made a Declaration of Friendship and one thing led to another and all I remember was me saying just....one....more....turn.I ended up playing the tutorial for ~6 hours straight. Yes. 6 HOURS ON THE TUTORIAL, AND IT WAS GLORIOUS. I ended up panicking and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at the fact that I could not save my progress, but I digress, it was the tutorial after all. Nowadays I find myself using my spare hours to play this meth like game. My grades were rekt, my relationships were rekt, my reading life was rekt, my League career was rekt and my plans to play Bioshock Infinite were REKT.All in all I give this game a 20/10 and reccomend you pick it up now that it will be dirt cheap with the summer sale, only and only IF you would like to have some -Ghandi nuking you, Would you like to make a trade agreement with ENGLAND, cursing that damned jungle king Monty, and OH MY GOD THAT WOUNDER WAS ONE FREAKING TURN AWAY FROM BEING BUILT I JUST WASTED 25 DAYS OF PRODUCTION AND ONLY GOT A MEASLY 100 GOLD SANIADSUFLUDSBASFJDSBFJSFDSLFA- filled afternoons then this is the game for YOU!Life Status: rekt ☐ | not rekt ☐ | Tyrannosaurus rekt ☑

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Comparing Civilization V to contemporary strategy games is entirely pointless. Imagine if Modern Warfare had come out alongside Quake II. There is simply nothing comparable out there, not least because the strategy genre has become the province of indie developers and niche publishers. Civ V is a towering, AAA release with millions of dollars worth of polish in an era where questionably localized Russian titles are all that strategy gamers have to tide them over for months at a time. It's also a delightfully fresh take on a formula that has been slowly iterated on for more than two decades.The heart of the Civilization fantasy is unchanged. You still manage cities, developing them from rude collections of mud huts into gleaming modern metropolises. Vast armies and armadas are again at your command, waging global war for conquest, defense, or resources with everything from spears to nukes. The land must still be worked, the primordial wilderness tamed through your people’s sweat and blood. Your ultimate goal is yours to choose: Diplomatically unite the people of the world under your benign leadership, launch a viable colony ship into outer space, conquer the globe through force of arms, or create a glorious utopia through enlightened civility.Civ V's genius lies in the way that Firaxis has aggressively chopped the number of decisions that a player has to make during the course of a game while taking away almost none of the meaningful ones. As a hardcore Civ player, I appreciate some of these ancillary aspects of the design, but the removal of all the fat is unquestionably Civ V's greatest accomplishment.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												I played Civ 2: Test of Time back in the day. It was fun to explore, the city building was interesting, trying out new units was always enjoable, and then of course, marching an army to an opponent was a blast. Fast forward 10 years to Civ 5. Exploration is always fun. Seeking ruins, meeting city states, fending off barbarians and eventually finding your opponents is great. The reasearch tree in this game makes it incredibly difficult to choose: Do I build up my military tech, increase my gold income, push for some good culture wonders, increase my science, grow my city... etc. and every play can be done differently. I have a favourite tech path due to familiarity, but if needed, I will take any road. The variety in strategy for early game exploration, mid game conquests and late game domination is incredibe. I bought this game on the suggestion of a friend and it was the best money I have spent on a game. Do I recommend Civ 5? YES! GET THE GAME! PLAY WITH YOUR FRIENDS!Once you get past the initial learning curve, you will find that the exploration, development, strategy, and eventual victory will be incredibly satisfying and very addictive. I cannot wait for Civilization: Beyond Earth

content:
Posted: October 18, 2011
												It's not like this game is so obscure that it actually needs a recommendation, but I thought I would add one from the perspective of someone who has never played a Civ game until #5. I grew up on PC games and could have easily played any of the previous versions, but for some reason just felt this wasn't really my type of thing. Well, it took 20 years or so, but I can finally admit I was wrong. It's a really fun and extremely addicting game. That said, there is definitely a bit of a learning curve for newbies. I really had no idea what I was doing at first, but eventually it all gels and you start to see why the series has been so popular. I have no idea how Civ 5 compares to previous games, but from personal experience, I can at least confirm that it's most definitely a good place to start for those new to the series. If you are like me and was never really sure if Civ was for you, I say give this a try. You'll probably be addicted before you know it. Just... one... more... turn... ;)

It is indeed very complex and I am always learning new tips and tricks. Besides Skyrim, this is most definitely my favorite game on Steam. I give it 10/10 cupcakes.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												Civilization V, the game where you rerite history!At the time I am posting this I have 576.1 hours on Civ 5, and I've had this game for nearly two years. Less than 100 of those hours are spent on the Vanilla version of this game. If you buy this game only buy the Complete Edition.This is my favorite game of all time. It's pretty easy to learn how to play, but don't worry because each individaul civilization is different. The playstyle for a desert civilization like Arabia is VERY different than the playstyle for maritime civilization such as England. Not to mention that there are 5 different ways to win Civ 5.-TimeVictory is given to the Civ with highest score after the set time period is over.-DominationBashing Skullz and taking names!-CulturalIts complicated. It deals with the culture and tourism your nation outputs.-ScientificBe the first to reach the distant planet Alpha Centuari.-DiplomaticBefriend city states, make strong allies, and become the world ruler through the United Nations.*!*And if any of these victories sound boring or annoying you can turn them off*!*In Civ 5 you will decide how to deal with:~Barbarians~Foreign Nations and Relations~City States~Religion~Religious Wars~Actual war with blood and bullets~GOD DAMN MONGOLS~Exploration~Expantion of territory~Expantion of military influence~Trade~Guilds~Espionage~Military Coups~Nuclear War Heads~Archaeology~World Congress / United Nations~And MUCH MUCH MOREI would recommend this game to not only turn based strategy gamers and fans, but anyone who has the patience to nurture a small group of settlers and warriors in 4000 BC into a thriving World Power of 2075 AD.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												For all time strategy fans this game is a must buy. The almost flawless take on a turn by turn strategy franchise makes the game not only stand out against it's competitors in the industry but also allows the game to boast it's golden reputation and show off its most impressive new features. While there are a few unbalanced things in the game such as how a millitary victory is much easier to achive than other means, the game still manages to get that tone between being complicated enough for veterans of the series and welcoming to newcomers. the change from squares to hexagons is a bold one, but yet again maxis an their brilliant team have done it again. like i just mentioned, the game has changed to hexagons rather than stayed at squares and the game surely flexes it's muscles, but you probably knew that already, what you really want to know is what have Maxis done to the Civilazation series. Did they break it? After all the series has never seen such a huge overhall before and it's assuming the title from a game thats earned it's golden reputation. Well im not going to make your mind up for you old veterans of the franchise but civilization's 5 blows each competitor out of the water one by one. EVERY animation in the game has been redone, the AI is much smarter (though that still dosent make them smart) and the diplomacy pannel while it may be lacking in many ways compared to games like Crusader kings, it is a massive improvement. For more on civilization 5, and boy is there a lot more, buy the game on steam now. This game really has shown us what companies can do when given unlimated time and money (look at gta 5) and lastly this game it appears will stand the test of time...

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Best Test of Time game?Extremely easy pick...since this is a game exactly about that.I'm getting very close to 1000h of playing this (and you better believe almost every minut of it is non-idle time) and I don't even own it since it was released but got it some years later.I've been playing Civilization games since the third installment, liked the previous ones but this one, this one just consumed me whole. Why did it do so? Simple answer - User friendliness. Everybody can play this game and win, but only the biggest brainiacs can truly have it "around thier pinky finger". And after tasting that initial "victory for dummies", it was so pleasurable and I really felt that I deserved it that I just wanted more and had to pushed myself further.This game made me learn most of it's "under the hood" mechanics and that includes reading a lot of related forum posts while I should be working, watching many hours of related YouTube material, not having enough sleep because I was thinking about playing it first time I wake up the other day and of course playing the actual game in all of it's variaty.Tested all the difficulties, acheived all victory types, tried out many maps, built all the wonders, made my friends hate me for a short time after I kick their asses in multi, played almost all scenarios (yes, those exist within the game you people who never even clicked on "options" in your life :P) and I just don't see the end of it (nor wish for it).Yes, there were times when I literally had to force myself to play something else so I wouldn't go (entirely) nuts. But the test of times is passed with the highest mark as I always return for Just...One...More...Turn.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Well then, the time has finally come to review what has occupied my life for the past months. Oh Civ 5, how I underestimated you this past summmer when I saw your GOTY edition on steam. How I was hesitant to buy you and thought your gameplay was boring. If only I knew...I bought this game out of pure review score, which of course -being a 90- I assumed was something special. As many of the steam games that are bought during sales do, it sat on my library quite some time while I was busy murdering Teemos on the Fields of Justice. When I finally got tired of that, I decided to check this game out, so I double clicked on the icon, and went into the game with little to no prior knowledge of what lay in store ahead. I booted up the tutorial, grabbed my water and said, "Well Civ 5, do your worst."I was greeted by a Morgan Freeman like voice, telling me about America and its past, along with some facts about George Washington. This narrator got me so pumped up; the combination of music, the epic dialouge, the VOICE, mother of god THE VOICE, I had so many goosebumps running over my body that I could hardly contain myself! And then I did it, I pressed Begin Your Journey, little did I know this would take me above and beyond what I believed was a true gaming experience. It started out simple, a settler and a warrior unit, and some lady telling me to found a city. I plop it down and start producing a monument, moving my warrior around and reasearching pottery. I found my neighbor soon after, the Incas, and I was greeted by a stunning display screen with a great voice actor and interface. Soon enough I had made a Declaration of Friendship and one thing led to another and all I remember was me saying just....one....more....turn.I ended up playing the tutorial for ~6 hours straight. Yes. 6 HOURS ON THE TUTORIAL, AND IT WAS GLORIOUS. I ended up panicking and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at the fact that I could not save my progress, but I digress, it was the tutorial after all. Nowadays I find myself using my spare hours to play this meth like game. My grades were rekt, my relationships were rekt, my reading life was rekt, my League career was rekt and my plans to play Bioshock Infinite were REKT.All in all I give this game a 20/10 and reccomend you pick it up now that it will be dirt cheap with the summer sale, only and only IF you would like to have some -Ghandi nuking you, Would you like to make a trade agreement with ENGLAND, cursing that damned jungle king Monty, and OH MY GOD THAT WOUNDER WAS ONE FREAKING TURN AWAY FROM BEING BUILT I JUST WASTED 25 DAYS OF PRODUCTION AND ONLY GOT A MEASLY 100 GOLD SANIADSUFLUDSBASFJDSBFJSFDSLFA- filled afternoons then this is the game for YOU!Life Status: rekt ☐ | not rekt ☐ | Tyrannosaurus rekt ☑

Posted: July 17, 2015
												Civilization V, the game where you rerite history!At the time I am posting this I have 576.1 hours on Civ 5, and I've had this game for nearly two years. Less than 100 of those hours are spent on the Vanilla version of this game. If you buy this game only buy the Complete Edition.This is my favorite game of all time. It's pretty easy to learn how to play, but don't worry because each individaul civilization is different. The playstyle for a desert civilization like Arabia is VERY different than the playstyle for maritime civilization such as England. Not to mention that there are 5 different ways to win Civ 5.-TimeVictory is given to the Civ with highest score after the set time period is over.-DominationBashing Skullz and taking names!-CulturalIts complicated. It deals with the culture and tourism your nation outputs.-ScientificBe the first to reach the distant planet Alpha Centuari.-DiplomaticBefriend city states, make strong allies, and become the world ruler through the United Nations.*!*And if any of these victories sound boring or annoying you can turn them off*!*In Civ 5 you will decide how to deal with:~Barbarians~Foreign Nations and Relations~City States~Religion~Religious Wars~Actual war with blood and bullets~GOD DAMN MONGOLS~Exploration~Expantion of territory~Expantion of military influence~Trade~Guilds~Espionage~Military Coups~Nuclear War Heads~Archaeology~World Congress / United Nations~And MUCH MUCH MOREI would recommend this game to not only turn based strategy gamers and fans, but anyone who has the patience to nurture a small group of settlers and warriors in 4000 BC into a thriving World Power of 2075 AD.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Civilization V is a strategy game by Firaxis Studios that supports both multiplayer and singleplayer. Unlike other strategy games I know, (*Cough cough* Starcraft II *cough cough*) this game does not have as huge of a learning curve to it. I was introduced to it at a fairly young age as both my brother and father were avid fans of the series. You start off usually by doing a single player game. Before you dive into the actual gameplay you must set up your game. First you are given a choice of factions, of which there are many. My favorite for the classic Civ is Egypt, while in Gods and Kings it is the Huns, and in Brave New World it is Brazil. After you select your faction, you select your land type (islands, continents, fractal etc.) and game length. Getting started can be tough, but the helpful "Advisors" will show you the way. There are many ways to win, so finding your play style will not be a problem either. As you player you contruct buildings to help with different conditions, and units to help defend against or conquer your enemies. Just like the real world, world wonders of all different varieties can be constructed for your empire as well, however only one of each may exist. There are many as well, ranging anywhere from the Great Wall of China to the Big Ben. The different victory types are diplomatic, cultural, domination, science, and time. I personally have only won twice with both victories being cultural as Egypt and Rome. In addition, there is endless replayability. With the many different world types and Civilizations to choose from, gameplay is endless. You will be investing hundreds if not thousands of hours on this game, I assure you. Multiplayer is something to brag about as well, I have never had a better time anywhere than playing with friends on Civilization V. There are two expansions to this game, Gods and Kings and Brave New World. Each of these expansions are worth every penny. In the end, this game is spectacular and one of my all time favorites. If you can afford it, pick it up immediatly or if you don't have the cash, wait for a sale and then do yourself the favor. This game and all of it's expansions combined earns a 95/100 from me. Fantastic, amazing, superb. Get it.

												Let me Start by saying that I tried this after my brother wanted me to get it a looonngg time ago. I couldn't understand the Politics and how to Micro-Manage everything. Put it down for a while. I had about 10hours of Trying.. Went to my brothers house after 150$ worth of DLC went on sale for 12$.... Bought it thinking "For when I get around to learning this, I want to have map packs, politics, etc" Asked him to come to my House and Start a game like he would at his own house, and kind of walk me through it (I am 27, but could not grasp how to have an eficient start (Sort of like chess)I noted his approach of how to put your Civ together and Take over parts of countries at a steady pace all while proctecting your own people. Have logged over 50hours in a Week or Two after not playing for almost 6 months. What a change of Events. Have moved up to King Diff because on Prince no one attacks you, you have to attack them, AND with a moderate amount of troops, you can just Run Over other Civs. Please. If you like chess, work for a living and have an hour or two to play at a time, Grab this game! The Cautious One

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												This game allows you to unleash the inner sadistic dictator that we all are underneath, burning cities and ravaging the countryside.   Engaging in a pre-emptive strike against Gandhi, I was able to keep him in the renaissance era while everyone else moved on into the modern era, preventing him from nuking me or anyone else in the future. In the meantime, I took part in the very practice I claimed to condemn and sent two consecutive atomic bombs to Amsterdam.   This game allowed me to engage in a foreign policy similar to the U.S.A.'s without the real life worldwide scorn and condemnation. 11/10   The only thing I would add to the game is the ability to stage false flag terror attacks, to further the realism.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												The base game is good with loads of ways to win and a game is never the same as the last, with some game taking 8 hours to even 50 hours or longer to 'win'. The game with all the dlc is great adding a few changes, but these changes just improve on some of the good aspects of the base game. There are lots of mods available here on the Steam Workshop as well as the  Civ 5 forum [forums.civfanatics.com] where there are countless amounts of mods to play with. Some of these mods are small but useful mods that give more information about your game while in game; other mods change visual aspects of the game. There are a set of mods called Community Balance Patch (CBP) that just revamp the whole game that you almost don't recognize it, making you almost have to relearn a whole new game. I barely have 280 hours and I know people in the thousands of hours. Buying this game  not  on sale is somewhat expensive. I would recommend to wait for the Steam Summer Sale where you can buy it 75% off for a price of $12.49. I'd r8 8/8 m8.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Oh Civilization V, what a masterpiece you are.Most of you who are interested in this game probably don't know the series. But Sid Meier's Civilization dates back to the 1991 and has span a long time. The second most recent was Civilization IV,  a game most fans are calling a masterpiece. With it's advanced gameplay, not fully broken diplomacy and a good mod community it was destined for greatness.Then this came a long.Civilization V is an amazing game. You'll be leading a Civilization through all of human history (And even the future) looking at how your civilization progresses. Will you wage war, and be a war mongler the world fears? Will you lead in science, and be the first to launch to a diferent world? Will you have all of the world succumb to your civilization's greatness? All of this is up to you.You have full freedom of what you want to do within the game. And it benefits from it. Since you can do whatever you want, you end up with fun scenarios, intensity, and essentialy some very satisfying gameplay.The visuals and the overall presentation is good as well. You get a very good cultural appropiate soundtrack while you're playing as a specific civilization, which is very neat. The best is especially the in-game rendered diplomacy screens. Where you will stand face to face with the leader you're discussing with. It is amazing the first time, and it's still awesome the 561th time.The only thing I'm dissapointed with is the AI. in the game. They tend to either be passive, or be down-right agressive. However there are mods fixing this, and you can always play multiplayer against/with other people. Which is a lot of fun in it self.The base-game is already a worth-while purchase, but can you afford it I'd suggest getting Gods and Kings as well as Brave New World. Both expansions add a lot to the vanilla game, and I personally can't go back to the normal experience.All in all, this is a must buy for any strategy gamer, whatever if one's casual or hardcore. You'll be spending a lot of fun re-(or just creating) historic events.Get this game as soon as you can, no doubt about it.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												An all around fantastic 4X RTS game, Civilization V, once it has the two major expansions (Gods & Kings and Brave New World) is an amazingly engulfing game.  So much of it is designed to pull you in and keep you wishing to advance your empire one more turn.  Winning the game can be completed multiple ways with large or small empires, and on higher difficulties victory can be a mad dash to the finish.  Combat is fun, and offers enjoyment in outwitting your opponent, or holding off large waves of enemies at a choke point.  The units are are crafted in high detail, and each civilization plays a slightly different way, letting you try a vast array of different strategies.The game is not without its faults, however.  The biggest of these issues is the AI, which can be confusing or downright moronic.  Additionally, while the shift to tactical-styled combat is a nice change of pace in the series, the AI doesn't seem to grasp how to make the most of its units and can make obvious tactical blunders with startling regularity.  The game's netcode and stability are also questionable at times once larger maps come into play, but when it is working play is smooth and almost seamless from one turn to the next.  All in all, an excellent game in a series full of well-made games.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												A very complex game that has a slight curving point for noobs. Though it takes a while to master it, it is still by all means my favorite game.The things I like about it: It has very fun scenarios such as the American Civil War, Scramble for Africa, and the Fall of Rome to name a few. There are a lot of countries to choose and master. It takes true strategy you can't just build a city and say you'll win (You probably won't with that overconfidence).A very good wide variety of maps too choose from. The multiplayer is amazing except for the fact that if you go to war with another human player you have to play in sequential order. The graphics are quite astonishing aswell.The things I dislike about it: There are no multiplayer Scenarios. :(Overall I give this game a 9.5/10Please leave any critizism in the comments. Thanks! :D

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Sid Meier delivered yet again with the latest, and debatably greatest, installment of the Civilization franchise: Civilization V.I'm not going to pretend I have played hundreds of hours on this game as you know I haven't becuse it says above(EDIT: yeahhhhhh, this game is addictive). But from what I have played of this game makes it one of my absolute favourites in my library.I personally am not usually the fan of strategy games because I haven't got the brain capacity to work out simple war strategies, but this game had me hooked from the begining. So much so, even, that I managed to convince my dad to buy it which he is now playing by my side religiously.I know I have tried and failed to sound intelligent so I will just say it how it is. BUY THIS GAME!!! The only fault i could possibly pick with this game is a few bugs that will inevitabley be fixed and the occasional crash. I would highly recommend that you save the game every 5 turns to avoid loss because of crashes. But what the hell do I know, maybe its my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ laptop's fault.All in all the game is very fun, highly addictive, seriously time consuming and life destroying but however needs some polishing 9/10

content:
Posted: October 14, 2013
History RewrittenI've never played any of Sid Meier's previous games and I'm a huge fan of Catan (a board/online game it reminded me of) so this automatically won me over. Civilization V is more complex than Catan in that it has more features to offer and it's more organized, requires more strategy so it's less random, and more relaxing depending on who you're playing with and/or what difficulty. You play a real historical leader, each equipped with their own perks to suit your desired win condition, and you choose how you want to interact with other leaders and their civilizations. You can build whatever you want, from armies to cities, as the technology and resources become available. It's addicting and so much fun alone or with friends. The game isn't the same without the DLC which I strongly recommend picking up.10/10 - JUNEBUG'S FAVORITES

												With the latest expansion, Brave New World, this is probably the best turn-based strategy game out there. Civ 5 has now reached the pinicle of the evolution of the Civ francise. I say this as a player who first played Civ over 20 years ago on my 386 and has played all the Civ games apart from Civ 2.Whereas most 90/early 2000s PC games that have been rebooted or updated in the last 5 years have been dumbed down as if developers think we are all xbawks kiddies with ADHD (I'm looking at you SimCity, Hitman, Wolfenstein, Thief, etc), the Civ series has actually been improved with time and has become a deeper game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2010
												Civilization V is an amazing turn based strategy game in which the goal is to rule the world through battle, culture, science, or diplomacy. The new hexagonal grid tiles allow for much more interesting gameplay than the previous games in the series. The game allows the player to choose from a variety real civilizations, each with their own unique perk, unit, and building.While this game features multiplayer capabilities, the games take a very long time to complete, and take more than most people are willing to invest in a single session. If you do have a lot of free time, it can be very satisfying to dominate the world with or against friends. I'd very highly recommend this game, particularily in conjunction with its downloadable content and expansions.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Civ V strikes a nice balance between the raw mechanics of the earliest Civ's (1&2) with improved polished gameplay of more recent installations. It does not suffer from overengineering in the same way that Civ 4 did, bless it's heart, however it is still full of intense micromanagment, which, if you're into it, is great. However it does potentially suffer from slow paced gameplay, which isn't an issue for single player, but can stymie attempts at satisfying online play - nothing is more dissappointing than a heated game against a human player being inturrepted by an apologetic blip on your Steam interface with the message "sorry, gotta dip, wife's giving birth!" Which is all the more frustrating because his wife was only eight weeks along when you started playing, and still had two weeks to go when you guys hit the Industrial Era.But srsly, Civ V is polished, offers plenty of opportunities to win and undermine your opponents, and has better replayability than just about any contemporary game in existence - multiple vanilla victory conditions, and multiple paths to fulfill them, along with copious and creative mod options means losing is a matter of multiple missed opportunities, rather than the result of a single split second blunder, like spilling your Red Bull all over your desk, and getting domeshotted faster than a sophmore loses it in a burlesque house (like every workaday, unispired clone of last quarter's FPS rhyming with fall love fruity). Also, given all the mechanics to experiment with one should never be bored with Civ V in their inventory. You will never beat it on hardest difficulty. It's an in joke by the coders. That's what I tell myself every night to fall asleep.Final score: 39 out 42 Chichen Itzas (pronounced "Chicken Pizzas")Pro advice: Play Industrial Era start, Huge map, against 22 Ghandis for a special treat, epescially if you're an 19th century journalist who enjoys getting slapped around by Barronesses exclusively wearing furs.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2013
History RewrittenI've never played any of Sid Meier's previous games and I'm a huge fan of Catan (a board/online game it reminded me of) so this automatically won me over. Civilization V is more complex than Catan in that it has more features to offer and it's more organized, requires more strategy so it's less random, and more relaxing depending on who you're playing with and/or what difficulty. You play a real historical leader, each equipped with their own perks to suit your desired win condition, and you choose how you want to interact with other leaders and their civilizations. You can build whatever you want, from armies to cities, as the technology and resources become available. It's addicting and so much fun alone or with friends. The game isn't the same without the DLC which I strongly recommend picking up.10/10 - JUNEBUG'S FAVORITES

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												I get to play as Russia settling in South Africa while attempting to build the Pyramids.10/10No but really, this game is pretty addicting. As there is little to no actual historical accuracy it does a great job of familiarizing you with ancient wonders, different civilizations, and ideologies. The game is great and has a lot of different things to try. Maybe one day you want to play with only Native American factions while playing on a Great Plains map; maybe another day you want to play with only the European powers on an archipelago map. Or maybe you just want to play as a faction and see how fast you can get Modern infantry and straight dominate a hunter/gatherer faction. This game has it all. With added mod support via Steam Workshop, there is always something or someone new to try out.
