number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												One of the best turn-based strategy games I have ever played. Starting from the pre-historic era and having to explore for a good place to settle your first city, you then have to scavenge and trade with other leaders to increase revenue and protect city states from barbarians to gain access to their goods. You can play the game any way you want. If you want to be a tyranical leader who's goal is to kill everyone and take their land as his, or you could win the game through strategic trading and tourism. The tech line is intuative with many ways to get where you want to go in the game. This in depth game with a diverse number of leaders and a great atmosphere always has you watching your back, making allies, signing treaties from previous altercations you had with that nation, and being the most dominent power by the end of the game in order to win. Yes, this game takes a while for a single game to finish, but with every second being like the first one you've had since trying the game the first time it will always keep you smiling and excited for what comes next. Don't even get me started on the multiplayer. XD I can't wait to play this game again! 10/10

I wasn't surprised how much it evolved - it has been 20 years since the first Civ after all. But was amazed by how much of the good stuff I remembered stayed basicaly the same. I haven't played it enough to be sure yet, but this game might be the best strategy game ever. The only flaw is that it will eat up all your time.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Sid Meier's Civilization V is a turn-based strategy game, falling into the 4x genre of video games. It is the Fifth game of the series and was released in 2010. You play as the leader of a civilization, such as; Ramses, Washington, Khan, and must develop your civilization to grow and settle new area's, including through diplomatic, economic, or military means. There are several conditions for victory you can play toward, and each turn represents several years in your civilizations time. Civilization V also has a new feature known as City-States, individual settlements, who are independent of the computer controlled civilizations, and operate as their own entities, making alliances, declaring war etc. Having had limited experience with the series, only playing Civ 3 for less than an hour several years ago, I came into Civ V with little expectations. I found it to be relatively easy to learn, the tutorial process and advisor tips help shorten the learning curve, and is actually fun. I found the AI to be interesting, as each player civilization and city-state has it's own personality. I haven't tried any of the Downloadable content, such as; Gods and Kings, or Brave New World; However, I can assume they only add to the fun you will have with Civilization V. Normally, I don't care for turn-based games and prefer real-time strategy, but Civilization V was a pleasant surprise. It was easy to learn, graphically, it looks a lot like the Total War games. If you like turn-based strategy games in the 4x genre, give this one a try.

My Family: They had gone on holiday multiple times without me ever noticing because of Civilization V.2. My Girlfriend: I truly loved her more than anything. We were the best couple. But she quite never understood why I always spent time with Sid instead of her. She then asked me to choose between her and Sid. As you can imagine, without hesitation, I chose Sid. 3. My High School Diploma: There usually isn't much time to study when you're playing Civilization V 25 hours a day.4. My University Diploma: Refer to point number 3.5. My Future & Humanity: Sums it up.However I also gained some things;1. A best Friend: His name is Sid Meier and he is the best!2. Knowledge: I am considered the foremost expert in World History.3. Wisdom: I now know that I should never trust Indian people and the natives of the Shaka tribe. NEVER EVER!4. My Virginity: Speaks for itself, does it not?10/10 would nuke the s**t out of Catholic Indians in South America playing as the Muslim Japanese in Europe.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												They say that history is what shapes us to be men. To be men of the future. To overcome the problems we've encountered before so we don't repeat them again... It's true for the most part. But, sometimes we, as men, do things that we believe is best for our sake, since we, as humans, are inevitably selfish. And there is no overcoming our greediness. Our lust for power, for things that we want the most. You may not agree, but I will tell you a story to prove this. It is a pretty dramatic story, mind. Starting out with nothing but a vision and willpower, Gandhi scrambled as many people as he could to lead, to turn them into soldiers that live to protect their home. They travelled across the uncharted lands to settle down in. He was respected among his men. He was a wise man. He was patient, and caring. Never was there a ruler who was so ... peaceful. Who had his wits about him when making his decisions as a great ruler. He was a man who never wanted war.Then he stumbled upon Genghis Khan... a tyrant... a visionary... a man without fear...  looking his way to conquer every civilization there is. But, Gandhi did not flinch. He wasn't scared of this Mongolian peasant! Ohhh, no. Gandhi does what he does best ... play it cool. He respectfully told him to stay away from his lands. The little Mongolian didn't like that. Not one bit. Eventually, they grew to hate each other. But, Gandhi knew Khan was more powerful than him. So, he built Delhi, and Mumbai, and with the resources he built with his people, ventured out to find more civilizations, and grew close with Ormus, Sofia, and Valetta. The former two had only a formal connection, but Valetta was the ally that proved fruitful. Eventually, Gandhi meets a mysterious, but a beautiful woman, who turns out to be a Chinese Sovereign - a Huangdi by the name of Lady Wu Zetian of China. Gandhi was smitten by this woman's graciousness, and was immediately prepared to conquer for her. He wanted to woo her. He wanted to impress her. To prove to her that he is the greatest of them all. Of course, this was no easy feat. As Gandhi built his empire, Khan's plans were unknown. But, as time passed, paranoia got the better of Gandhi, as the very thought of Genghis Khan taking the hand of his beloved Lady Wu angered him. It filled him with bloodlust. It turned a good man ... cruel. He abandoned all thoughts of taking care of his own cities. And focused more on building his military power. While the relations between his civilization, Ormus, and Sofia were deteriorating, Valetta stood beside them, and gave them the units they needed to defeat Genghis Khan... and it was time. Khan set up Beshbalik, near the outskirts of Delhi, to make Gandhi feel powerless. Gandhi saw this, and finally, the unthinkable happened. He snapped... and sent his units to Beshbalik. Thus ... the first war of the world began. It was long. It was bloody. It was brutal. To think that a man of peace who settles with wearing dhotis would go crazy for power would render anyone speechless. Khan offered peace many times. But, Gandhi wasn't having any. He didn't want peace. He wanted a war. So many lives... the soldiers, the horses, the workers ... all perished as the war went on. Both sides lost a lot. But, Khan's forces proved stronger, as he was allied with Kathmandu, his best performing ally, who abandons him eventually, and Prague, their most passive. So, Gandhi took a step back, and gathered his wits to take the time to make a stronger army.At long last ... after losing any relations he had with previous civilizations, after losing even Valetta, after throwing away every single shred of dignity he had for humanity ... He conquered Beshbalik in 100 AD. And then, Khan offered peace yet again. But, this time, Gandhi accepted. And so, the war was over. Annexing Beshbalik instead of razing it, in hopes of bringing up a civilization there, Gandhi celebrated his victory by laughing maniacally. But, soon, it dawned on him. His love. His beloved Huangdi. And so, he set off to Guangzhou. And there she was. As beautiful as she was the first time he met her. He offered the city to her. With all of his heart. Asking nothing in return. A city ... a whole city ... for this majestic beauty. And he smiles gleefully, as she accepts. He returns to Beshbalik to gather his troops to return to Delhi. All the way imagining her by his side, as his beloved queen, conquering every civilization there would be. Oh, the sweet feeling of victory. Finally, he was going to get everything he had ever dreamed of.He arrives. He finally arrives at the city. But... but what's this? Oh, no. To his horror... he sees the camps ablaze. Men, women, children ... the whole city on fire. Razed to the ground. By his own love. A city he fought for, for his own love. For years. All that time spent on fighting for a city, losing the many men that fought for the very city he wanted to gift to his beloved, only to have it burned to the ground by her. Why? Why would she do that? How could she be capable of such atrocity!? He loved her! He fought for her! Well, too bad the game doesn't have RPG elements, otherwise, we could've known why.10/10 Would fight Genghis Khan for control over Beshbalik for over 2 hours just to gift it to Lady Wu Zetian of China only to have it burned to the ground. I spent 6 straight hours playing the game very seriously ... only to find out later that it was the tutorial. Heh.On a serious note, the game does have a major problem with the cinematics, so if there's a chance you're facing start-up problems, for example a black, unresponsive screen, you'll have to modify/delete the cinematic files of the base game, and the cinematics of the DLC's - Brave New World and Gods & Kings. This is the only downside I had with the game. DO BUY IT!

Posted: October 4, 2016
												I could never get into this game like I got into Civ 4 and its mods.- It doesn't have the gloriously inspiring Baba Yetu music on its title screen ;)- Global happiness means I don't care about my individual cities, thankfully Firaxis recognized this and are bringing back city happiness with Civ 6.- Mods are nowhere near as awesome as Fall from Heaven 2 for Civ 4. Modding support was much delayed, as well.- While in theory I like the introduction of the hex grid for more wargame-like tactics, one unit per tile means a lot of tedious shuffling when you must move all your army to a new front. Some kind of stacking for travel or strategic move (see: Hearts of Iron series) would've been necessary.Doesn't mean it's not a good game, just a disappointing compared to previous installments. I'm still gonna play it from time to time hoping that with the expansions it suddenly "clicks" with me.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												This game asks one simple question: Can you build a nation that will stand the test of time?Its not an easy question to work out "yes" to if you're looking for a challenge. The AI might be random at times or it might be entirely logical, But from playing it I've learned you should always keep on your toes. Outside of easy, the computer players can outmatch you but not just militarily - unless you hit the ground running you can be quickly overshadowed.This incarnation of the Civilization franchise makes a lot of changes, namely the switch from a grid to hexagons and the removal of the ability to stack units. Some people loathe this but after playing it i've found the whole thing less of a meatgrinder; no throwing your army at a stack of 23 armies on one square, no 31+ stack of armies lying in wait when you attack an enemy city. In fact the system makes it more viable and likely to surround a city (which is what happened in most wars by the way) rather than charge headlong at it with a bulk army. Every detail of the world is beautifully rendered, sometimes I found myself panning the camera over my and my enemies' civs imagining what life is like in the piece of Earth they have carved out.Gods and Kings and Brave New World - its epansions - at a ton of variety to the game. The culture victory option for example, involves tourism and cultural influence, which is how places like America, Japan and the UK ingrain their cultural mannerisms elsewhere in the real world.The game is not just beautiful on a strategic level; I'm a fan of history and culture and this game is bursting at the seams with it, especially with Brave New World; every technology has an associated quote be it a passage of a holy book, a line from a Greek, Roman or Shakesperian play or a phrase coined by a legendary person. Every world wonder you complete shows you an oil-on-canvas painting of it complete with a quote that relates to its purpose or its reputation, in the second expansion your great people can world-renowned paintings and compositions which you, the player, can enjoy for yourself. It makes you want to build wonders even more if this is your kind of thing.Whether you're an empire builder at heart, passionate for history, love high culture or just enjoy watching burning everything to the ground. This is a worthy addition to the franchise so get this, get the expansions too (even if you're nonreligions, Gods and Kings adds a lot of other stuff to the game), this game would be ideal for you.Just don't expect to be done in a three-hour session; Civ is not a game for the twitch player. Its famous for that.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Have you ever once looked into yourself in a self-reflective manner, contemplating existence as you stared into a mirror, and wondered?:"What would it like to have George Washington and Genghis Khan duke it out against eachother in a battle for world-domination?"With Civilization, you can accomplish this.CiV is not a game that requires many reflexes; in fact, it requires no reflexes at all; it trades this in for being vexingly complex, filled head-to-toe with different stats and numbers and other things which will have your mind moving faster than it would in your average game, but your mouse much slower. Whether this is a "good" or "bad" characteristic depends on your tastes; if you like action-packed FPSes filled with massive explosions and a fervor of button-tapping, CiV will disappoint you. If you like calming, casual puzzle games where you mix and match coloured gems or other such objects; CiV will disappoint you. However, if you like spending hours slowly building up your empire, moving military units to resources and strategic positions, and discussing diplomatic policies with AIs or your friends with a similar lack of a social life; CiV will *not* dissapoint you; in fact, quite the opposite.CiV is interesting as it has a variety of different playstyles; perhaps you want to create world peace as Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden? Or send a spaceship to Alpha Centauri as Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon? Or raze across the land like a fire, destroying and conquering all in your way as Attila of the Huns? CiV endorses multiple different playstyles which make the game interesting; and different civs have different abilties which make others better at some playstyles; most of which are *fairly* balanced, although some civs can't help but be somewhat mediocre (e.g., America, The Ottoman Empire [before BNW], The Iroquois Confederacy), at least in comparison to others.If a single-player game seems to drag on for too long, CiV has a solution; multi-player. You can team up with your friends for a co-op, split up into tag-teams and viciously try to take eachother down, or even play an "every man for himself" strategy. The one problem is that, unfortunately, multi-player does seem to have quite a few glitches; although these aren't game-breaking, they can be quite the nuisance at times. I'm somewhat hopeful that Firaxis will make an attempt to deal with some of these.To end this short, spur-of-the-moment review; CiV is a game I highly suggest; unless you want to have a social-life, as buying it -and, hence, becoming addicted to it- will often severely damage your "life" to the point of being unsalvageable.

But then that button keep staring at me, like saying, "end your turn now!". I tried and I tried to end my turn, but it never stop. I need to develop so my country won't be left behind, i need to conquer, I need to be there for my people. So every turn became an obsession, I feel compelled to stay. I WANT TO KNOW MORE! I WANT TO FEEL MORE!So yeah, it take longer than two hours. This is the greatest strategy game on planet earth, easy to play, hard to master.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
For all of its more controversial elements and related failings, the hours I’ve spent playing Civilization V make it quite obvious; this is still one of the most varied and consistently satisfying games that I’ve played to date.With dozens of different civilizations to choose from (America, Mongolia, China etc.), each with their own unique abilities and bonuses, no two games are likely to play out quite the same way and as such, Civilization V is a tough game for strategy fans to get bored of.As Arabia you might seek to establish a lucrative trade network and ‘buy’ yourself friends using your mountains of dosh, as England you might construct a powerful maritime nation and go on the offensive with enhanced frigates and longbows, and as France you may instead choose to wow the world with your awe-inspiring culture and devotion to the arts; ensnaring people to your ideology with that time honoured brand of “polite terrorism” that is tourism.The two official expansions to the game only seek to refine it further with the official releases Gods and Kings and Brave New World both adding a raft of additional features including new civilizations and wonders, religion, espionage, trade routes and an expanded culture game including great works and archaeology.In every new game I find myself drawn not to the most powerful strategies, but instead to the ones that intrigue me the most. It’s a testament to the game’s diverse palette of “boardgamey” elements that make every setup so unique and rife with potential.Ultimately, my favourite aspect of Civilization V is the mere fact that it’s a game you can get really good at by using your own approach. This is a game that just keeps paying off as you come to appreciate the finer aspects of tile yields, unit movement and preparing for events that will come hundreds of turns from where you are now.An essential title for fans of 4X strategy.Read the full retrospective at my blog »[www.celjaded.com]

												Sid Meier's Civilization V is a great strategy game that new and old players of the Civilization franchise will love. It combines great AI with complex strategy mechanics to immerse the player into his own empire made from a vareity of cities and military might that the Civilization franchise specializes in. However, the only downside to this game is the lack of interesting scenarios that only pricey DLC can supply. But despite the scenario problem, Civilization V is a fun and exciting game to play with friends or by yourself against the difficult AIs. I recommend this game.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												Addicted. I need help!... Can't stop... Just one more turn....I'm a re-newb to the genre so I won't go into technical and comparison.To any other newbs I recommend checking out the Steam Community guides if you find yourself overwhelmed by the plethora of set-up options and want some frustration saving strategy hints. Totally worth a little reading time.Very few games out there keep me playing after the main objective has been met.  I can't even properly describe why... why I can't stop. Once you get past the initial learning curve it becomes seductively simple and almost hypnotic. You'll be all like, 'Hey, I can have this running and do a turn here and there while I'm getting on with something else'... 4 hours later... 'I'll do it in a minute, just one more turn...'Graphically, it's a pleasant enough mask for the clever mechanics. Many ways to play and win. Nice array of buildings and units, Stealth and Nuclear Missile being my favourites... "Oh! Hello. Looking round my border are we? BOOM! ¡SƎHƆ┴Iq I'll melt your faces off and rub my butt all over your tiles!" The UI is uncluttered and easy to find your way around. Tooltips and tutorial messages and in-game help are surprisingly helpful. The community is active and awesomely creative. The achievements are plentiful but stretched across DLCs.Recommended for people with time to spare.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Please love yourself and get this and all the DLC next time it goes 75% off, which is relatively often.I'm not sure how veterans to these sorts of turn-based strat games find it, but to a total newcomer like me the mechanics are rich and complex. It takes a while to become familiar with how everything works (I'm 150+ hours in and I'm still discovering things) but that just makes it more enjoyable in my opinion. You get out of it whatever you put into it. If you're super serious and looking for a challenge, this has it. If you're interested because you've heard of the potential hilarity that can ensue, this certainly has it. The worldbuilder DSK that comes with the game is also very enjoyable, especially if you're a writer or an artist. It's a great source of inspiration.

												There are many paths you may take. You may take the wonder path and build so many wonders you may be considered a God, or you may take the world domination path and FORCE them to consider you a god. Maybe you hate earth and decide you want to conquer the stars (as if Earth wasn't hard enough); so you decide to build a rocket and escape. Oh wait, I forgot you are a nice guy.... So instead you should go and create a giant organization and present yourself as its head. Don't want that either? Then just live for about 450 turns (a couple millenia) and die of old age. There are many paths to choose from, but how will you pave it?

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												Do I recommend it? Yep!Civilization V is a game I recommend. However I only recommend for those interested in games that require thinking on your next move, rather than acting on impluse. Civilization V is a game where you can be a country, and lead it from the ancient era to the "information era," the most advanced era in the game with the best tech. Such tech including a giant death robot which you can use to thump war other enemy giant death robots! Or smaller units. Like infantry... But the giant death robot always wins. Although its mostly them just fighting in other ways in short animations. But wanna get those really fast? Well you can adjust the pace of the game. Thats right! From a normal quick paced game that can end shortly, to a pace that can take about an entire 3 days to really complete or so! Anyway... As I was saying, you can be a country... The game provides loads of information on each civilization, (Being your country) and leader who you play as of that country. This can be a very fun role playing game for many who would seek to like "alternate history." You can even name your own country and all, making it even more suitable for roleplayers. Such countries may include China, Russia, America, England, the Celts, Mongola, Monocco, the Aztecs, Inca, and many many more! I've played almost or more so over 500 hours of this game, and I simply love it.One thing I can say gives this game a boost is its scenaros. These are games players can choose from, like a Steampunk styled scenaro, a Invasion of North Korea by Japan with their samuri, (Which believe me, I have an epic story to tell because of this one.) and even choas in midieval England, where you must fight to retain the throne from countless waves of invaders on all coasts and fronts, who are even fighting themselves. (Which made me rage quit.) Without this, I would most likely be "meh" towards this game. You can even be one of the invaders if you'd prefer!Do I recommend the DLC? Yes! I recommend getting the DLC first hand if you are interested in buying this game. The DLC which added the U.N. (Being "Brave New Worlds") is a fascinating idea for the game, and can be used as a weapon against other players in multiplayer games. You can ban resources, (That you think might be immoral. *Cough* Roleplayers.) and really deal striking blows to your enemies. But beware, as you might blow indirect hits to other players as well, hurting your country in the long run, as they invade you just so you will vote to unban oranges when the next world congress is summoned!Another great reason to buy this game, is the mods. These mods can be resource mods, civilization mods, mods to make your game feel better (Such as making units seem more epic by scalling down their size and making more of them. Making combat look extra epic.) and many other mods. There are even many mods for Bronies. Wanna fight an evil insane Pinkie? Do so as Twilight Sparkle or Princess Celestia! Heck, wanna BE Pinkie? Build some "cupcake factories" and get producing those weapons! Because for you, the sun might be just coming over the horizon... Rainbow Dash fan? Yep... Daring Do? Yep! Want Pony advisors instead of those boring ol' regular ones later on? You can do that. And each mod with these seems to me to be wellfully done, making them feel like they are really part of the game. Wait, whats that? You've ponified your game so much but are still bored of always fighting on the Earth map? Well... A mod can change that. Such as the "World of Equestria" mod, which I must say is a very epic change of pace for any Brony players. Maybe even non-brony characters... Maybe.So this is my review for Civ V. Strongly recommended for stradigy peoples and also just simply recommended for roleplayers who like country type roleplays! I mean, I could also direct those people to NationStates, but... I feel I already just did. So buy this game. With the DLC. Its freakin' epic. Don't get mods right away either. Go. No. Just buy it... Go! Get it!The choices are yours on what you want to do in this game, be it either you warmonger or you try to be a global police force, or even just an isolationist. If you have any questions for me, please ask, and I'll respond to them. There is quite a lot I ended up leaving out. I didn't want to make this to long and boring, especially since it isn't like this is in video form.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Sid Meier's Civilization V is a roundbased turn-based strategy, 4X ( = eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate) game.I'll review and recommend this game together with its expansions, as those DLCs add important things to the main gameplay, making this game so outstanding good.If you like games like Crusader Kings or the Total War series, you definitely should check this one out. (There are of course some minor to major differences)You pick a leader/country for a game and have to reach different goals for different victory conditions.My (formerly) most played game on steam, here's why:+ addictive as hell+ high replay factor+ you get so much game for your money+ every country/leader has different strengths+ you'll be able to play against friends+ lots of diplomacy and different victory conditions+ it is so much fun to watch your empire grow+ every game you start is quite different+ with DLCs: there is now religion and even more ways to win a game+ many different characters, with DLCs: even more different characters+ Graphics are actually neat, can look quite nice but does also run on older pcs (I guess)About the music: Some parts of the soundtrack are very nice and beautiful, but after playing a long time they can get repetetive and annoying, so it's neither really bad nor good.Some small things do bother me:- I guess this is a matter of taste, but I think there are way to many achievements, like 280 of 'em.- the scenarios are quite boring- sometimes I feel like you should have more diplomacy options and sometims it's annoying how fast another nation dislikes you (but I guess this is somehow realistic =)- Battle is really simple, if you want a similar game with more focus on battle/war, try the Total War Series (e.g. Medieval or Rome 1)Overall, this game is giving you extremely many hours of gametime due to its addictive gameplay and I guess you'll easily get plus 100 -150 hours with this one.Rating:94/100

content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												It's an exhausting game to play, but once you have the BNW expansion, it's also one of the best strategy games you'll get your hands on.**Edit:** I have now played the game long enough to know what all my quirks with the game is. I still believe it's a really good game. For a future Civ game, i'd LOVE to see a pitboss mode that allows you to use a shared steamcloud save, and gave steam notifications when it is your turn, rather than having a dedicated server running hosting the game 24/7 while it is played (which could be months potentially).A pitboss mode like this would be even more attractive if a future civ game was focused more around optimization and lightweight-ness than pretty polygons. The perfect civ would be an epic game spanding several months, where it'd take you 20 seconds to sign in, take a turn, and leave the game again.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												gandhi nuked me xD that's not supposed to happen because gandhi was peaceful lol actuallyMohandas Karamchand Gandhi (/ˈɡɑːndi, ˈɡæn-/;[2] Hindustani: [ˈmoːɦənd̪aːs ˈkərəmtʃənd̪ ˈɡaːnd̪ʱi] ( listen); 2 October 1869 – 30 January 1948) was the preeminent leader of the Indian independence movement in British-ruled India. Employing nonviolent civil disobedience, Gandhi led India to independence and inspired movements for civil rights and freedom across the world. The honorific Mahatma (Sanskrit: "high-souled", "venerable")[3]—applied to him first in 1914 in South Africa,[4]—is now used worldwide. He is also called Bapu (Gujarati: endearment for "father",[5] "papa"[5][6]) in India. In common parlance in India he is often called Gandhiji. He is unofficially called the Father of the Nation.[7][8]Born and raised in a Hindu merchant caste family in coastal Gujarat, western India, and trained in law at the Inner Temple, London, Gandhi first employed nonviolent civil disobedience as an expatriate lawyer in South Africa, in the resident Indian community's struggle for civil rights. After his return to India in 1915, he set about organising peasants, farmers, and urban labourers to protest against excessive land-tax and discrimination. Assuming leadership of the Indian National Congress in 1921, Gandhi led nationwide campaigns for easing poverty, expanding women's rights, building religious and ethnic amity, ending untouchability, but above all for achieving Swaraj or self-rule.Gandhi famously led Indians in challenging the British-imposed salt tax with the 400 km (250 mi) Dandi Salt March in 1930, and later in calling for the British to Quit India in 1942. He was imprisoned for many years, upon many occasions, in both South Africa and India. Gandhi attempted to practise nonviolence and truth in all situations, and advocated that others do the same. He lived modestly in a self-sufficient residential community and wore the traditional Indian dhoti and shawl, woven with yarn hand-spun on a charkha. He ate simple vegetarian food, and also undertook long fasts as a means of both self-purification and social protest.Gandhi's vision of an independent India based on religious pluralism, however, was challenged in the early 1940s by a new Muslim nationalism which was demanding a separate Muslim homeland carved out of India.[9] Eventually, in August 1947, Britain granted independence, but the British Indian Empire[9] was partitioned into two dominions, a Hindu-majority India and Muslim-majority Pakistan.[10] As many displaced Hindus, Muslims, and Sikhs made their way to their new lands, religious violence broke out, especially in the Punjab and Bengal. Eschewing the official celebration of independence in Delhi, Gandhi visited the affected areas, attempting to provide solace. In the months following, he undertook several fasts unto death to promote religious harmony. The last of these, undertaken on 12 January 1948 when he was 78,[11] also had the indirect goal of pressuring India to pay out some cash assets owed to Pakistan.[11] Some Indians thought Gandhi was too accommodating.[11][12] Nathuram Godse, a Hindu nationalist, assassinated Gandhi on 30 January 1948 by firing three bullets into his chest at point-blank range.[12]His birthday, 2 October, is commemorated as Gandhi Jayanti, a national holiday, and world-wide as the International Day of Nonviolence.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
For all of its more controversial elements and related failings, the hours I’ve spent playing Civilization V make it quite obvious; this is still one of the most varied and consistently satisfying games that I’ve played to date.With dozens of different civilizations to choose from (America, Mongolia, China etc.), each with their own unique abilities and bonuses, no two games are likely to play out quite the same way and as such, Civilization V is a tough game for strategy fans to get bored of.As Arabia you might seek to establish a lucrative trade network and ‘buy’ yourself friends using your mountains of dosh, as England you might construct a powerful maritime nation and go on the offensive with enhanced frigates and longbows, and as France you may instead choose to wow the world with your awe-inspiring culture and devotion to the arts; ensnaring people to your ideology with that time honoured brand of “polite terrorism” that is tourism.The two official expansions to the game only seek to refine it further with the official releases Gods and Kings and Brave New World both adding a raft of additional features including new civilizations and wonders, religion, espionage, trade routes and an expanded culture game including great works and archaeology.In every new game I find myself drawn not to the most powerful strategies, but instead to the ones that intrigue me the most. It’s a testament to the game’s diverse palette of “boardgamey” elements that make every setup so unique and rife with potential.Ultimately, my favourite aspect of Civilization V is the mere fact that it’s a game you can get really good at by using your own approach. This is a game that just keeps paying off as you come to appreciate the finer aspects of tile yields, unit movement and preparing for events that will come hundreds of turns from where you are now.An essential title for fans of 4X strategy.Read the full retrospective at my blog »[www.celjaded.com]

												Please love yourself and get this and all the DLC next time it goes 75% off, which is relatively often.I'm not sure how veterans to these sorts of turn-based strat games find it, but to a total newcomer like me the mechanics are rich and complex. It takes a while to become familiar with how everything works (I'm 150+ hours in and I'm still discovering things) but that just makes it more enjoyable in my opinion. You get out of it whatever you put into it. If you're super serious and looking for a challenge, this has it. If you're interested because you've heard of the potential hilarity that can ensue, this certainly has it. The worldbuilder DSK that comes with the game is also very enjoyable, especially if you're a writer or an artist. It's a great source of inspiration.

Learning how to play is easy, becoming a master requires a lot of trial and error. It took me roughly 200 hours to master a vanilla strategy and will probably take me another 200 to master my strategy with the expansions. This has been one of the few games in my library and it probably will stay that way for a while. Find some friends, grab a drink, and play for hours while you crush them.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2012
												Civilization 5 has had an interesting journey over the years and remains the game I have most likely wasted the most time on. But do not think it is perfect in any ways, it is as flawed as a game can be.I will not waste time on Single Player as the AI is either unfair on Diety and it is a challenge so far that you have to play one exact way to win or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly stupid and all you do is haul those wonders and wait for a time to attack. Their attack strategies are mediocre at best and even with number advantage you are able to defeat the opponent without any issues. But there is a reason I only played Civ Beyond Earth 30 hours and this game since then 500 hours. And it is the Multiplayer.Back in the day I used to play Civ 3 with some buddies on Hot Seat Mode and that was a blast, so going into Civ 5 I started playing MP right away and have not been disappointed, well I have been but more on that later.The team games are awesome, they require great tactics and strategy and are highly competitive given you play with the right group. FFAs are plenty and can be fun too, there is nothing more rewarding than winning a 6 hour game. At the beginning there are several ways to be competitive and one has to make quick and rash decisions on whether to build wonders, cities or units. There is a default way to be effective but one still has to analyse its territory. With the addons this just becomes better as one has to decide whether to go for that early pantheon, how to deal with city states and potential neighbors. Sometimes an early rush is the only option you have to succeed. This is what makes the game great, you are required to make game altering decisions quickly and early. It is not like AoE where you can play with a preset mindset as sometimes it just dont work out. When you are playing as Babylon, a science powerhouse, but you see yourself surrounded by 2 players, your typcial play by rushing Great Library will not be possible anymore.With all the updates and addons I do have to say I like the current setup of Wonders as well as the selection of Natural Wonders. There are some which are gamebreaking and are usually banned, e.g. Great Wall. But I do like them as a adjustment to your game. The Natural Wonders are IMO also quite nicely balanced, except of course El Dorado and the Fountain of Youth, which are rare spawns. The 500 Gold equalizes an early Settler buy or 2 workers, which gives you a great advantage to do anything. Fountain of Youth gives you 10 happiness plus higher Reg, you can expand without worries for a long time. But it is possible to still defeat a person with these wonders, something that can be rewarding. The Tech Tree I always had my issues with as it is pretty locked and sometimes offers little room for strategy. There are some techs which are game deciding, Crossbows and Navigation the most apparent ones. Later one as the tech tree branches out one has to make a decision on getting certain techs while neglecting others. One of the toughest decisions is always on whether getting Public Schools or Artillery, Science or the 3 range unit. Early on I always play a default setup, I rarely adjust it to the start. C
